blog.name: angelofberlin2000
blog.title: Like a Rose trampled on the ground
blog.description:
In addition to the pain and the exhaustion, he recalled how waiting on the cross between takes became tedious. To fight the boredom, he listened to music on headphones. One particular song called "Above All" (Like a Rose ...) by Michael W. Smith helped him through his most difficult moments.

"It arrived when I was confused and angry. I didn't think I could go on. The song described how Jesus was rejected and alone. That thought took me to a place — it opened an interior door that held me while on the cross," an emotional Caviezel explained. "The experience of feeling rejected and alone as all those around me laughed while drinking their hot coffees, oblivious to what was occurring. Jesus must have felt like this — forsaken, rejected, alone, and despised. It helped me pray in a very deep way — to pray without words, to pray from the heart. The discomfort, the loneliness, the split shoulder, the raw flesh all forced me into the arms of God because I had nowhere else to go for a performance I knew I was unable to create."
Jim Caviezel, Shamelessly Catholic

summary: My older sister had a *major* crush on Keanu Reeves back in the mid-90s. She loved Speed. Thought the Dracula accent wasn’t that...
title: My older sister had a *major* crush on Keanu Reeves back in the mid-90s. She loved Speed. Thought the Dracula accent wasn’t that bad. Even adored A Walk in the Clouds. ‘Isn’t this a wonderful movie?’
body:
Me: ’I dunno, can’t he just stick to killing people in The Matrix  and avenging his dog? Frankly, I find A Walk in the Clouds mediocre.’

I didn’t say this, of course.It was, like, 1997. I was only 10. And I did not have access to a time machine. 

But if I had access to a time machine, I would have said this.

reblog.comment:

I didn’t say this, of course.It was, like, 1997. I was only 10. And I did not have access to a time machine. 

But if I had access to a time machine, I would have said this.

trail.content_raw:
Me: ’I dunno, can’t he just stick to killing people in The Matrix  and avenging his dog? Frankly, I find A Walk in the Clouds mediocre.’

I didn’t say this, of course.It was, like, 1997. I was only 10. And I did not have access to a time machine. 

But if I had access to a time machine, I would have said this.
trail.content:
Me: ’I dunno, can’t he just stick to killing people in The Matrix  and avenging his dog? Frankly, I find A Walk in the Clouds mediocre.’

I didn’t say this, of course.It was, like, 1997. I was only 10. And I did not have access to a time machine. 

But if I had access to a time machine, I would have said this.

summary: I can not afford what I like
title: I can not afford what I like
body:
February 10, 2015 at 1:29 amI can not afford what I like. tagesanzeiger, February 8, 2015Kann mir meinen ich nicht Kunstgeschmack Leisten, tagesanzeiger.ch, 02/08/2015
InterviewAnlässlich der Paul-Gauguin-Ausstellung der the Fondation the Beyeler liest Keanu Reeves Schauspieler der aus dem Tahiti-Tagebuch «Noa Noa». Dabei ist seine Begeisterung für das Werk des Malers ziemlich neu.  

Translation: Evgenia Degtyarev
“I can not afford what I like”
In connection with the Paul Gauguin exhibition in the Museum of the Beyeler Foundation, actor Keanu Reeves performs with the Noah Noah artist’s Tahitian diary. At the same time, the admiration of the author’s works for Keanu is something new.“His paintings - it’s almost a mental challenge, the emotions are so strong!” A fan Gauguin Keanu Reeves in front of the painting “Nafea faa ipoipo” (When is the wedding?): Photographer Georgios Kefalas

Keanu Reeves arrived in Basel on a mission: He was, in part by blood Polynesians, like would open the eyes of the public to the great French innovator Gauguin. We talked with the star Matrix and Velocity in the winter garden of the Beieler Foundation the day before his speech.

Keanu, you will read excerpts from Gauguin’s Noah Noah’s poetic diary. By what criteria did you choose the text?
I would love to read the entire diary, but unfortunately, for this I do not have enough time. I will read an excerpt from each chapter and tell something personal to this topic.

Where did the enthusiasm for Gauguin’s work come from?
This is something completely new to me. So far I have heard about Gauguin only thanks to Anthony Quinn.

He plays in the movie “Thirst for Life” in 1956, is it a classic of Vincent Minelli?
Yes. Kirk Douglas plays there Van Gogh, and Gauguin Anthony Quinn . He plays great. Now that I know Gauguin’s biography better, I understand that I really liked Quinn’s game very much.

And now?
Of course, I have seen some of the works of Gauguin before, those that everyone knows. But after I agreed to Sam Keller (director of the  Beyeler Foundation ), I began to read Gauguin - his letters and diaries. He is a very persuasive writer. It suddenly seemed to me that I had entered into a discussion with a living artist.

Are you interested in Gauguin because you yourself became a writer?
Do you mean “ Ode to Happiness ”?

Yes, your poetic consideration of Gogenov’s themes.
I can’t compare myself with Gauguin. But in my book, it’s really about how to regain happiness after dark events. Everyone experiences it from time to time.

Gauguin had such times even in his own created paradise.
There is a popular belief that he even painted paradise. Only when you really look at his paintings, it is clear that this is not so.

Not? How do you interpret this?
He seduces the public with the promise of paradise, this is true. Gauguin was a great seducer. But ultimately, he was faced with the understanding that life is more bitter than sweet and doubts remain about who we are and what we are. Thus, on the contrary, paradise does not exist.

So, is Gauguin more honest about this than other artists?
Here, in the Beyeler Museum, there are excellent opportunities for comparison. And I noticed yesterday during the tour that many great artists are honest about it. However, I find Gauguin in this sense especially aggressive. His paintings are almost a psychological challenge, emotions are so strong! He is striking, makes him understand and not to condemn. It almost seems to me that his paintings reflect the views of the audience looking at them.

It sounds almost as if you were his relative … Is it possible? It is said that in Polynesia whole islands are inhabited by the descendants of Gauguin.
Well … part of my father’s family are natives of the Hawaiian Islands, this is very, very far from Tahiti and the Marquesas. But aren’t we all Gauguin’s children?

How strong is your connection with the Polynesian culture?
As a child I visited my cousins ​​in Hawaii. But Hawaii, let’s say, is very American colonized. Nevertheless, I notice how dear to people are the remnants of a distinctive culture, how attached they are to it.

The manner of treatment of Gauguin with the population of Tahiti has been criticized by feminists. Do you personally, as a Polynesian in part, it is not disgusting?
I read that some people perceive him as a sex tourist or even as a pedophile, because some of his women, for example, were only 13 years old. And I have to admit, the way he describes these things does not justify him at all. For him, there is only himself and his paintings, as well as family. All the others meant little to him. On the other hand, he often finds tender words describing women from the islands. This tenderness is also reflected in his paintings.

Do you also collect paintings?
No, I can not afford what I like.

Oh, it sounds like you want to buy a painting by Gauguin “When is the wedding?”, Which just changed ownership for 300 million and is last exhibited at the Basel Museum.
Well, see? I can not afford it. Fortunately, there are museums. Great art must be accessible to all.

via https://vk.com/keanurussianclub

via https://vk.com/keanurussianclub

The manner of treatment of Gauguin with the population of Tahiti has been criticized by feminists. Do you personally, as a Polynesian in part, it is not disgusting?
I read that some people perceive him as a sex tourist or even as a pedophile, because some of his women, for example, were only 13 years old. And I have to admit, the way he describes these things does not justify him at all. For him, there is only himself and his paintings, as well as family. All the others meant little to him. On the other hand, he often finds tender words describing women from the islands. This tenderness is also reflected in his paintings.

Do you also collect paintings?
No, I can not afford what I like.

Oh, it sounds like you want to buy a painting by Gauguin “When is the wedding?”, Which just changed ownership for 300 million and is last exhibited at the Basel Museum.
Well, see? I can not afford it. Fortunately, there are museums. Great art must be accessible to all.

via https://vk.com/keanurussianclub

blog.name: angelofberlin2000
blog.title: Like a Rose trampled on the ground
blog.description:
In addition to the pain and the exhaustion, he recalled how waiting on the cross between takes became tedious. To fight the boredom, he listened to music on headphones. One particular song called "Above All" (Like a Rose ...) by Michael W. Smith helped him through his most difficult moments.

"It arrived when I was confused and angry. I didn't think I could go on. The song described how Jesus was rejected and alone. That thought took me to a place — it opened an interior door that held me while on the cross," an emotional Caviezel explained. "The experience of feeling rejected and alone as all those around me laughed while drinking their hot coffees, oblivious to what was occurring. Jesus must have felt like this — forsaken, rejected, alone, and despised. It helped me pray in a very deep way — to pray without words, to pray from the heart. The discomfort, the loneliness, the split shoulder, the raw flesh all forced me into the arms of God because I had nowhere else to go for a performance I knew I was unable to create."
Jim Caviezel, Shamelessly Catholic
